name: The Bakeshop on 20th

attributes.Ambience: {'touristy': False, 'hipster': False, 'romantic': False, 'divey': False, 'intimate': False, 'trendy': True, 'upscale': False, 'classy': False, 'casual': True}

categories: Coffee & Tea, Bakeries, Food, Soup, Breakfast & Brunch, Restaurants
llm_reasoning: 88% - Reviews repeatedly describe it as a coffee shop and mention coffee drinks, supporting its classification as a cafe despite heavy bakery offerings.

text: Takes forever if you order a sandwich. I like supporting small businesses, but they have to speed things up. Everyone was waiting so long and one of the young girl workers was just standing there on her phone the entire time.

We rolled in - new girl today is on the cash register.  Misheard me and then she and the owner get involved "defensive and Patronizing.  Then apologized and rolled her eyes. I know the owner of the building.  Not a revisit for me. Too many other choices with fully trained and developed people who speak professionally and warmly. Service business

Everything LOOKS nice but meh... it's very average and nothing special. It's not really worth going to. 

They have a small selection of goods and the employee I dealt with (maybe it was the owner?) didn't smile at me once and was a bit rude - kind of off-putting, considering they've been open for maybe a month? I stopped in for an afternoon cup of coffee and a cookie - the cookie tasted like it had been sitting out all morning.

I was not greeted with a simple hello or even a smile upon entering this establishment ... just weird looks which should have been my cue to exit and take my business elsewhere but since I walked a few blocks for a cookie I decided to push through. 

I ordered 3 cookies and each of them had very strange textures, taste, and smell (yes the smell was off). I just couldn't eat them, the only saving grace was the coffee which was decent tasting. 

Judging by the reviews I was hoping to cure my sweet tooth but nope ... on to the next one ...

I'll start by saying the drop in stars is not due to food quality- everything I get from here is amazing. However, they are becoming more popular for breakfast sandwiches and such, especially on the weekend. While I'm happy people have discovered the deliciousness it has caused the wait times to become outrageous....they simply don't have the capacity to meet demand. I went in for an avocado toast the other day and was warned it would be 10-15 minute. Ok No prob...went to get a smoothie a couple doors down. Came back, waited almost 30 minutes for avocado toast! Spread bagel can churn out orders at triple the speed. Unfortunately I will hold at 3 stars until they figure out how to be more efficient.

So maybe we got the wrong thing for breakfast, but the savory breakfast sandwiches were not particularly warm with soggy flatbread. The bacon in the bacon egg and cheese was good, but the rest of the sandwich was nothing to write home about. I think I would prefer McDonald's egg mcmuffin to this bacon egg and cheese sandwich. It would have been nice if the sandwich was toasted and assembled in a reasonable time. To make matters worse, there was no room inside as friends of the workers were sprawled over the table and pushed closer to the window so that the rail at the window was not accessible. Overall it seemed like we were inconveniencing them by trying to order something besides pastries

Slow, disorganized service.  The lady behind the register was distracted while taking our order, she seemed to prioritize a friend who had walked in, serving her before all the others on the line.  Took several minutes for them to give us our iced coffee while those who ordered after us had no problem getting their drinks.  However, my boyfriend said his sandwich was pretty good.

I'm so happy I finally got to try this place after seeing all the foodie-blogger Instagram photos of sprinkle-covered cracked open cookies oozing rainbow whatever in someone's manicured hand.

Stopped in here on a Friday morning around 10 after a doc appointment and decided 'work can wait,' so made a beeline for this place, which was poppin' with regulars and newcomers alike.  Looks like something out of a movie, super cute and old-timey.  Stereotypically hipster, if that makes sense.  I was greeted by one of the best selections of overflowing multicolored sweets poised in glass that I ever laid my eyes on.  I'm a visual learner, so if I can't SEE what I'm buying, I probably ain't gonna buy it (why TF do so many other bakeries not display all their shit?).

Anyway, I also heard from a coworker that their breakfast sandwiches were dope, so I ordered to-go a turkey bacon/egg/cheddar on a bagel ("Philly Muffin") and a nice selection of 6 different carefully-chosen pastries (so hard to not just say, "I'll take the lot!").

The wait for my sandwich took longer than expected, but they were definitely busy with both in-house customers and Postmates/Caviar orders during the morning rush.  I was able to get a better look at all the different varieties of non-bakery foods they offered, as well as what looked to be really great, locally-sourced coffee.

For my sandwich and sweets it came close to $40 (yikes), but I would estimate that each pastry was probably like $4-5 each (they're MASSIVE), so makes sense, especially when I went in there no-holds barred on the budget.

Overall, my sandwich was okay (I was a little underwhelmed actually).  The Philly Bagel (essentially a square English muffin, but seasoned like an everything bagel) would have been better on its own with just butter (it was too soft and I like a bit of a bite to my sandwiches, like an actual bagel or a kaiser roll).  The egg was cooked fine, but the turkey bacon was not crispy at all and too thick-cut.  Next time, I'd stick to something a little more classic.

As for those pastries, the bike ride to work then back home that night jostled TF outta them, so a few fell apart.  My absolute favorite was their ricotta/Italian wedding cookie. My mom and I have made these every year for Christmas since my birth and they've never come out that good - absolutely perfect.  Will probably go back and just get like a dozen of those.  Others were 2 cinnamon/raisin cookies, a tahini chocolate chip cookie, a strawberry oat bar, and a birthday cake blondie.  The blondie was my second favorite, but very very sweet.  The oat bar and cinnamon cookie were too floury, almost like a biscuit.  So, a hit or a miss depending on what you get.

Overall, I would like to come back and try some more.

Wow.  This is probably one of the BEST bakeshops I've ever tried...I am having a hard time not going back RIGHT NOW even though I was just there an hour ago!  I ordered the chocolate cinnamon babka which is basically a cinnamon roll with chocolate baked into a muffin shape with extra gooeyness...I scarfed down that whole (huge!) thing in like 5 minutes.  I got a croissant and the famous Rittenhouse Square to go (well that was the plan but then I bit into the rittenhouse square 5 minutes later and it was amazing).  There were SO many other things I wanted to try (the cookies looked fantastic, as did the scones).  I didn't try the sticky bun and I agree with the Yelper who said that Flour in Boston is the standard, but based on what I tried today I would not be surprised if this is at least equal if not better...

Why the 4 star review instead of 5?  The service was unfortunately NOT up to the level of the baked goods.  The servers got easily overwhelmed and did silly things like: 1. I asked for the babka for there and the other things to go and they gave me everything in a to go bag with the babka in the bottom and the rittenhouse square on top not fully wrapped up spilling caramel over everything else in the bag, 2. they ran out of coffee and my friend nicely handed them the pot to refill and they forgot about refilling it - twice - so she had to ask several times and finally got the coffee 25 minutes later, 3. they gave my friend her sandwich, then 20 minutes later tried to give her another one because they forgot to throw out the order tag from the first one and though she ordered a second one and 4. as we were sitting there eating they got a few other people's orders wrong and just seemed incredibly flustered...

If they can just iron out the kinks in the service this would be the hands down winner for best bakery in Philly (OK OK all you other Yelpers can fight me for that but I'm standing strong!)

Spent a night in Philly a couple weeks back and wanted to pop in somewhere for a quick breakfast before heading out in the AM. Yelp came to the rescue after a search for breakfast sandwiches yielded this little gem. The plan going in was for my husband and I to each get a breakfast sandwich and to take a (one) cookie and a (one) treat to-go to bring to my grandmother who we were visiting and has a sweet tooth. When we walked in our plans were completely de-railed because everything in the case looked so good! We each got a breakfast sandwich and a cold brew - he got a bacon egg and cheese on an everything philly muffin, and I got smoked salmon avocado toast on an everything philly muffin - which we ate at a table outside and both were fresh and delicious. Their "serve yourself" cold-brew was great, and I liked not having to explain to somebody how full I wanted my cup. That brings us to the sweet treats. They were sampling a cherry "pop tart" which was fantastic. I normally hate cooked cherries because they stop tasting like real cherries but this was lovely, not too sweet and still tasted like real fruit. We then got a Maple Oat scone, a chocolate chip cookie, something with apricot (bar maybe), and one other thing that I cant remember to go. When we got to my grandmothers and sat down for some sweets and tea every single item was delicious. The scone was traditional but not too dry, the apricot was a total winner - we were all fighting over the last bits, and the cookie while a touch too sweet had tons of chocolate and great consistency. I will say that we noticed that they had forgotten 1 of the item we ordered but we didn't check our order before leaving and also ordered in a such a scattered way that I can't really fault them for it. If I lived near this place I would certainly come back, and often.
i took a bite of this cookie and then passed it off to my dog i didn't realize it was a dog treat! worst cookie ever! a couple minutes later i heard him barking for more.

Ordered a breakfast cookie and when I asked whether there were peanuts in it the answer was "I don't know, there is a nut mix in it so I would rather you not take the risk". I later learned this was the owner I was speaking to. It's pretty ridiculous when the owner of a bakery doesn't know the ingredients in her products. So disappointing.

If there's one thing you want to do right in life, it's you need to get the ricotta cookie here.  I really was not expecting the level of goodness that came from this cookie.

My friends and I got to Philly super early on a Saturday and it was my duty to search for a breakfast spot.  Bakeshop on 20th was constantly coming up in all my searches, so we decided on here.  

It is an adorable little shop (literally, there's only about two tables inside and two tables outside) and 80% of customers coming in seemed like regulars.  The girls behind the counter knew a couple of customers by name.

Anyways, the three of us decided to get a breakfast sandwich, which you can customize.  My friends decided to get it as is, but I opted to get mine on a croissant.  When I checked in on Yelp, I noticed that there was a deal to get any cookie for $1.  I mentioned this and showed it to the cashier, and picked the ricotta cookie.  So glad I decided on this.  The sandwiches took awhile to come out but we had that cookie to taste.  I split it 3 ways, so my friends could try it.  Let me tell you how blown away we were.  It's been 3 weeks since the visit and we are still talking about this cookie.  It was just the right amount of sweetness, so soft and chewy.  The bites with the icing part are event better!  You get that extra sweetness from the glaze.  Wow.  I don't know if there is a secret to how they make their ricotta cookie, but I'm about to try and make my own and they better turn out the same way lol.

The breakfast sandwiches came super fresh and piping hot.  All the ingredients were of quality and it was actually too big for me.  I could not finish it.

We have our usual spots we always need to visit whenever we are in Philly and Bakeshop on 20th has now made the cut.  Next time, I'll be sure to buy a dozen of those ricotta cookies. =)))))

You walk into a cozy space, that's maybe a little too cozy you think, as you bump elbows with the other costumers. If you're just grabbing a sweet treat and coffee, the line moves fairly quickly.  The coffee bar is located in a seriously inconvenient spot, right to the side of the door, yes, right in the middle of the elbow-bumping fiasco.  If you're hoping to fuel up on a sandwich the wait is immensely long (roughly 20 some minutes). Consider yourself warned that the wait time maybe longer than anticipated by the staff taking orders. The food itself is pretty decent. The long awaited sandwich was hearty and made with fresh ingredients. The coffee cake we tried was really tasty. This wouldn't be my top choice if I'm grabbing breakfast or brunch on the go but perhaps if I just need a sweet treat I'd swing by.

Major danger zone if you have a sweet tooth. Cute little place with lots of mouthwatering baked goods on display.

However, I was pretty annoyed to find that the coffee prices are a lie: the price she billed me was way higher than what's on their board, because it "hasn't been updated" - not cool. And the coffee is self-serve, anyway, which is fine, but what am I paying extra for?

But I will give them points for having a generous plate of samples by the register, and a creative assortment of flavors! I tried the fig and brie scone (delicious, and super filling) and the berries and cream babka (fantastic! Haven't seen babka in that flavor before, but it totally works). I also had a bit of the Rittenhouse square (crumbly cookie-like base, with a brownie on top, covered in caramel and a pretzel - messy, but very yummy), and the coffee cake (good!). 

Overall, I'd definitely go back for some sweet sweet carbs, but probably not coffee. (If I could give half stars I'd give 3.5, but unfortunately that's not possible).

---

Edit: Thank you, Lisa, for your response. I believe I was charged $3.78 for a cold brew - is that the correct amount? I paid in cash and am not local, so I am unlikely to be returning anytime soon regardless. If the listed prices are correct, however, the larger issue is that your cashier told me that they were not.

I believe the reason I can only give this place for three stars for now is because we probably come here too late so we couldn't try their most popular bakery items (Sticky buns & Babka muffin). 

We ordered "Apricot scone" & "Walnut oat bar" with a cup of cold brewed coffee for our first time visit. 

[Apricot scone]: I'm not a big fan of apricot, but this was the option left with the fruit topping. Their scone was unexpectedly soft & was not too sweet, which made me want to come back to try their other scones.

[Walnut oat bar]: It had a thin layer of jam in the middle part of the bar (probably strawberry jam) and it was pretty sweet. The oat layers were also sweeten and covered with powder sugar, which made the entire bar too sweet. It was too heavy & dense to me to eat the entire piece or without coffee/unsweetened drinks. 

My advice is that you should visit this place early if you want to get their signature/popular bakery items. And we're planning to come back one more time to get the full experience!

A co-worker brought some treats from Bakeshop on 20th into work earlier in the week, so of course had to try it out myself over the weekend! The Bakeshop is a tiny little spot tucked away in Rittenhouse, but for the small place, people definitely know it's there. I was actually surprised at how short our wait was (maybe 5 min to place an order), but customers were in and out the entire time we were waiting for our treats to be ready. The staff was incredibly kind, providing recs to us as we were deciding what to order and sharing some insider tips (AKA follow them on Insta to see their specials for the weekend!). 

For our eats, it was SO hard to make up our mind! To not completely overwhelm ourselves with sweets, my finacé and I split the bacon, egg, and cheese sandwich. The egg was a fluffy patty, and the bacon was nicely crisped, all encased in a whole wheat ciabatta bread - not the most memorable breakfast sandwich, but solid. To indulge in the main attraction, we split a chocolate babka as well. Man, SO GOOD! They also offer fruit babka, but our eyes were set on the chocolate and I feel that we made the best decision :) It was so flaky yet dense (but not too dense) and chock full of melty chocolate. Truly a wonderful treat! The babka is quite filling since it is a bit dense, so highly recommend splitting it with a friend. We couldn't limit ourselves to just this treat though, so we snagged a chocolate chip cookie ($1 with Yelp check in!) and homemade pop tart (!) to go. The chocolate chip cookie was a no brainer with the coup, and it was pretty nice - big chocolate chunks with some sea salt on top encased in a thick cookie. Pretty standard fare, but quite good! But the pop tart...we originally weren't going to get, but when they told us it was a weekend special AND it was their last one (!), we had to get it. Strawberry was the feature for the week, and it was delightful. The crust was so flaky and it was iced with the perfect among of icing as to not overwhelm the pastry. The filling was incredibly fresh with actual pieces of strawberry bursting from the seams. So glad we were convinced to try it! 

Overall, we loved our Sunday AM at Bakeshop on 20th. There were SO many pastries to choose from, it was hard to narrow! 100% recommend the chocolate babka and the homemade pop tarts. We will certainly be visiting again to try some other pastries (eyed the scones) and some coffee too!

"... I lived a few weeks while she loved me." Humphrey Bogart, In a Lonely Place (1950)

It's one of the minor tragedies of my dessert obsessed life that I've never lived close to a great or charming neighborhood bakery. Never. The closest I came to was walking 16 blocks to Payard Patisserie, when Monsieur Payard still had his UES location. Other than that, they've all been long subway rides. I suppose I should be thankful as who knows what my LDL would have been otherwise! 

So, a couple of years back, while working on a project in Philly, imagine my surprise and delight to find this delightful and unassuming bakery  just a few minutes' walk from me.  I'd be here for breakfast, lunch... and cookie break - and wonder why people were lining outside nearby Carlo Bakery instead of making their way here. 

The Bakeshop had/has everything: freshly made sandwiches using top notch and fresh ingredients on great English muffins (a truly magnificent Avocado Toast Special), innovative items like the Rittenhouse Square (caramel covered brownie on a somewhat salty graham cracker base) and Brookie (brownie + cookie), and regular bakery goods that were/are better executed here than at most places (scones that weren't dry or crumbly, chocolate babkas, gluten-free chocolate cookies). In those days, the amazing baker Meg (of Nutmeg Cake Design) would share the kitchen and one could hope to run across fresh cupcakes baked from ingredients remaining from the wedding she'd catered to. That would be the special treat ... on top of all the other sweet treats!

Sadly, as I moved away, I could no longer be a regular here. I still go back and sample what's available infrequently, and while I can understand the complaints about limited seating capacity and the $5 minimum credit card charge, and I'm not a fan of the (few) retail items that are not made in-house, I'd say that the Bakeshop is likely still the best bakery in the neighborhood.

I'm a cookie fiend, and I've eaten many a sweet treat in my life. Bakeshop on 20th has HANDS. DOWN. The BEST chocolate chip cookie I have EVER had. It's huge, filled with chocolate chips. It's sweet with a slightly crunchy exterior and soft, chewy interior. It's not crumbly or over/under-baked. I'm honestly unsure how such a perfect cookie could even exist. It's fairly rich and could easily be shared amongst two people if you're feeling generous. I had no problem polishing the entire thing before my breakfast even arrived at my table. I couldn't even manage to get a decent picture of the cookie (not that a photo would do any justice anyways) because I could not control myself from biting into it from the second it hit my hands. Additionally, check-in with Yelp and get the cookie for ONE DOLLAR, which frankly feels like robbery because it's just THAT good. 

I ordered the Salmon Special for $12. It was advertised as an English muffin, topped with fresh sliced salmon, cream cheese, capers, tomato, and onion. In my head, I pictured on of those small, store-bought English muffins. Uhm. No. It was a huge, whole-wheat, house made wonder packed high with tons of salmon. It was a heaping, delicious sandwich. I honestly could have taken half home for later, but again with the no self-control. I ate the whole thing and was full for the remainder of the day. 

If you'd blink, you'd miss this little shop. It's it a super cute area just west of Rittenhouse Square Park. They've got a fresh selection of cookies, scones, and other goodies baked in-house on display in a glass case. I'd imagine it'd be impossible to make a wrong choice here. Everything is delicious tasting and easy on the eyes. You can tell it's made with fresh ingredients and lots of love.

The inside of the shop is small and can easily feel claustrophobic. There's a handful of stools and a couple of tables, but realistically, the entire shop is only equipped to comfortably seat about 6-7 patrons. I felt in the way as I waited for my sandwich. I ordered my sandwich to-go, but it took about 15 minutes to be ready. Fortunately, I grabbed a free seat and perused some of their hilarious pug-themed novelty books. I'm sure the sandwich was freshly made, but I had no idea it'd take fifteen minutes. There were several patrons who came in after me, and I guess it just took longer than I'd expected. I'm just glad I wasn't in a hurry. 

Needless to say, I'll definitely be back next time I need a cookie fix. Come! Check in! Get a cookie! The food is great!
